I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about such an expansive range of music and revolutionary movements. I developed how I think about what qualifies as "revolutionary" and what praxis is.

I learned a lot about the research process in the humanities, as well as so much about revolutionary music throughout American history. In terms of insights, we talked a lot about capitalism and racism in the Americas and how that shapes every institution we interact with and therefore our perception of the world.

Exposure to social and political movements throughout the Americas through a musical lens. From reggae music and Rastafarianism in Jamaica to riot grrrl music and radical feminism in the States, this class provides in-depth insight to phenomena you may not otherwise have even known anything about.
I learned about how music can affect revolutionary movements and learned how to think critically and evaluate revolutions.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All of the content is a strength! Professor Davis has put together a really far-reaching but also in-depth curriculum that exposes students to so much powerful information about several movements.

I think that this course could be improved if there was a bit more of a clear direction for class each day. The best classes were the ones that were grounded in the music, as we tended to get off track kind of easily. Also, more feedback throughout the semester would be great- going into the final, we only had one grade, so it was difficult to know where we could improve in order to do well in the class. But the topic was fascinating and the readings were very well curated.

Strengths: week after week, the topics were always so amazingly interesting and culturally significant and politically relevant. The discussions flowed like rivers, often we'd find ourselves going over class time because there was still so much more to be said and we didn't want it to end! The instructor was an amazing facilitator and always knew just the right questions to ask or points to bring up so prompt further discussion. The podcast project was also really, really fun.

Weaknesses: the readings could be overwhelming. They were always so interesting, but sometimes it was just way too much. From time to time, I found myself being forced to skim what I would genuinely like to be reading, but could not always find the time for.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Davis was super understanding and honest with us the whole semester, which made being online so much easier since we were all kind of struggling together. She gave us space to cope with so many challenges and overall showed great empathy, the most important thing for getting through these difficulties. She also used the technology to her advantage since we depended so much on listening to music in class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would 100% recommend this class to any student who is at all interested in social justice, political organizing, and/or music in any capacity. This class is full of super interesting and thought-provoking readings and insightful conversations.

I would recommend this course if you are looking to dive into ideas about how racism and capitalism have really shaped music in the Americas, as well as getting exposed to a lot of music and revolutionary movements that are overlooked. The course is really what you make it because it's so discussion based, so if you come to class having done the readings, then the discussions will be great!

Yes. A million times yes. This course is one of the best ones I've taken at Yale so far, and I will seriously never forget it. The classroom became such a safe space of kind individuals who cared about the same issues and just shared a genuine love for music. Angharad was literally amazing, one of those professors you will never forget. And everything we learned about in class was literally so mind-blowing. This was the one class I couldn't stop talking about to my friends all semester long.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
